column4: How does one mount a removable drive if it wasn't detected automatically?
generally "sudo mount /dev/sda1 /media/removable"
k thx
and the drive might be /dev/sda or /dev/sdb  or /dev/sdc etc.  Or it might not be loaded because you are missing a driver.  Check that you can see when you type "cat /dev/scsi/scsi"
no such file and directory
Hmm... it's not detected... but it gets power
what is it?
A 40 Gig "External Drive Enclosure"

it is probably misconfigured then.  I assume there is a harddrive in the enclosure, you should check that it is plugged in all the way, that it is set as "master" or "cable select (CS)" with the jumper on the back of the drive, and that the drive size is compatible with the enclosure.  Some don't like big drives, some don't like small drives.
K, it's not mine - a frend wants some data from my PC, but I suppose it normally works for him...
most "just work".
Yeah I know. Never had this before. There are no buttons or switches on it... it's plugged.
try a different USB port.  It is 2.5" drive?
Desktop, and yes, it's 2.5
if it has an external power adapter you could try using it.  not all usb ports are created equal (which is why those drives have an "optional" power supply)
I see... I don't have an adapter. But it seems to have enough power (it stopped blinking when I plugged the power in
it might have enough power for the usb electronics but not the drive.  It might just not be supported.
Hmm... so I'll try switching them around a bit.
Is there a way to install some more external HDD drivers or something of the sort?
you could download "smart boot manager"
what is it and how does it work?
it is a floppy, you put it in your drive and boot from it, then it gives you a menu to select different devices to boot from.  Simple to use.
perfect. Where do i get it?
